definition: to pursue closely
tight/strict/close at hand/near/urgent/tense/hard up/short of money/to tighten
to chase after/to seek/to do one's utmost to seek or procure sth/to recall
to sculpt/to carve/musical instrument (old)

sentences.english: He took off after me, vainly trying to land a blow.
sentences.chinese: 他在後面緊追不捨，總想打到我。

sentences.english: Not far behind him was Lin Tao.
The hound nips at a rabbit.
sentences.chinese: 獵犬在野兔身後緊追不捨。

sentences.english: The police kept after the criminal until they finally caught him.
sentences.chinese: 警方對那個罪犯緊追不捨，直至最後把他抓獲。

sentences.english: The boy rushed past me with a policeman close on his heels.
sentences.chinese: 那男孩從我身邊飛奔而過，有個警察緊追在後。

sentences.english: The thief ran off down the road , so I chased him for all I was worth .
sentences.chinese: 那賊順着馬路逃跑，我就拼命緊追不捨。

sentences.english: The partisans managed to get away, although the enemy was hot on their tracks.
sentences.chinese: 雖然敵人緊追不捨，游擊隊員們還是設法跑掉了。

sentences.english: Wounded haze it running in the woods, the day a group of soldiers followed behind.
sentences.chinese: 負傷的嵐麼在樹林中奔跑，身後一羣日兵緊追不捨。

sentences.english: The shark, excited by the smell of blood and the chase, went after him.
sentences.chinese: 那條鯊魚受到血腥味以及捕食的刺激，緊追在他後頭。
併購狂潮緊追綠色趨勢。

sentences.english: The taxi driver saw him and ran after him.
sentences.chinese: 出租車司機看見了他，在後面緊追不放。

sentences.english: Top would be fine, but to be near the top would mean the run-in would present us with an opportunity.
sentences.chinese: 頭名當然好，但緊追領頭羊意味着我們還有機會。

sentences.english: Now in our school there is a hot pursuit of fashion.
sentences.chinese: 現在在我們學校有一股緊追時尚的風氣。

sentences.english: In most, though, he is nipping at Mr Romney’s heels.
sentences.chinese: 儘管大多數調查中，凱恩是緊追羅姆尼其後。

sentences.english: A snarling swarm of razor-toothed green monsters is hot on his heels.
sentences.chinese: 一大羣牙尖齒利的綠色怪獸在他身後緊追不捨。

sentences.english: He kept running desperately chased by two police.
sentences.chinese: 他拼命地逃，後面兩個警察緊追不捨。

definition: to oppose each other with equal harshness (idiom); tit for tat/measure for measure
to turn white-hot/to intensify/to reach a climax
to call loudly (idiom); to get people's attention/to make one's views known
to make way (for sth)
dangers spring up all around (idiom); surrounded by perils
to make an amphibious assault/to seize a beachhead/to gain a foothold in (a new market)
to take the lead
one falls, the next follows (idiom); stepping into the breach to replace fallen comrades/advancing wave upon wave
to surmount all difficulties (on the way to success) (idiom)/abbr. for 過五關斬六將|过五关斩六将[guo4 wu3 guan1 zhan3 liu4 jiang4]
(of a pendulum) to stop swinging/(of work, production, activities etc) to come to a halt/to be suspended/to be canceled/shutdown/(sports) lockout
to be a cinch/in the bag/(of a person) confident of success
to follow up a victory and press home the attack/to pursue retreating enemy
to dodge/to sidestep
to stick onto/stalemate/gridlock/to agglutinate
to glare like a tiger watching his prey (idiom)/to eye covetously
lit. to ruin the enterprise for the sake of one basketful/to fail through lack of a final effort/to spoil the ship for a ha'penny worth of tar (idiom)
